original_subgoals: Open the image in Photoshop.
Open the image in Photoshop.
Open the image in Photoshop.
Open the image in Photoshop.
Open the image in Photoshop.
Open the image in Photoshop.

subgoal: Select the object you want to remove using a selection tool such as the Lasso Tool, Quick Selection Tool, or Pen Tool.
original_subgoals: Select the object you want to remove using the Quick Selection Tool or Lasso Tool.
Use the Pen tool (shortcut P) to make a precise selection around the object to be removed.
Save the path for future use by renaming it in the Paths tab.
Convert the path to a selection by holding Ctrl (or Command) and clicking the path thumbnail.
Feather the selection by going to Select > Modify > Feather and apply a 1-2 pixel feather.
Select the Polygonal Lasso Tool and make a selection around the object.
Select the Lasso tool by pressing 'L' on your keyboard.
Use the Lasso tool to draw a selection around the object you want to remove.
Select the object you want to remove using one of the selection tools: Quick Selection Tool (W), Lasso Tool (L), Polygonal Lasso Tool (L), Quick Mask Mode, or Pen Tool (P).
If using Quick Mask Mode, paint over the object with a brush set to 100% hardness, opacity, and flow, then exit Quick Mask Mode to create a selection.
Select the Lasso tool by pressing 'L' on your keyboard or from the toolbar.
Create a selection around the object you want to remove, leaving some space around it.
In the Content-Aware Fill workspace, you will see a green overlay indicating the areas Photoshop will sample from.
Use the Eraser tool to remove any areas from the green overlay that you do not want Photoshop to sample from (e.g., parts of the object you are removing).
Invert the selection by pressing Shift + Ctrl + I.
Expand the selection if needed by going to Select > Modify > Expand and choosing an appropriate number of pixels.
Set the feather to 10 pixels and ensure Anti-Aliased is checked in the Options bar.

subgoal: Duplicate the layer to keep a clean copy of the original image (optional but recommended).
original_subgoals: Duplicate the layer to keep a clean copy of the original image.

subgoal: Use Content-Aware Fill to remove the selected object. If needed, use the Content-Aware Fill workspace to adjust the sampling area and preview changes.
original_subgoals: Use Content-Aware Fill to remove the selected object: Press Shift + Delete (Shift + Backspace on Windows), choose Content-Aware, and click OK.
If the result is not satisfactory, use the Content-Aware Fill workspace: Go to Edit > Content-Aware Fill, adjust the sampling area, and preview the changes.
Use the Lasso Tool to refine the selection area if needed and update the Content-Aware Fill preview.
Apply the Content-Aware Fill and deselect the selection (Ctrl + D).
Remove easy objects using the Clone Stamp tool:
Create a new layer.
Use the Clone Stamp tool to sample an area and paint over the object within the selection.
Deselect the selection with Ctrl (or Command) D.
Select the Spot Healing Brush Tool from the toolbar.
Paint over the object you want to remove and observe the result.
If artifacts remain, consider using the Content-Aware Fill tool.
Go to Edit > Content-Aware Fill and apply the default settings.
For precise removal, use the Content-Aware Fill with careful selection and exclusion of areas you don't want to sample from.
Go to the 'Edit' menu and select 'Content-Aware Fill'.
Use Content-Aware Fill by pressing Ctrl + Backspace, setting the contents to Content-Aware, and ensuring Color Adaptation is checked, then click OK.
For more complex backgrounds, use Edit > Content-Aware Fill to manually select the data for filling, adjusting the selection and preview as needed, then click OK.
Click on 'Generative Fill' in the Contextual taskbar and then click 'Generate' without adding a prompt.
Repeat the process for other large objects you want to remove, such as cars in the background.

subgoal: For further adjustments, use tools like the Clone Stamp Tool or Spot Healing Brush Tool to refine the image and remove imperfections.
original_subgoals: For further adjustments, use the Clone Stamp Tool: Create a new layer, set the tool to 'Current and Below', sample an area (Alt/Option + click), and paint over the imperfections.

To remove straight lines like power lines, create a new layer and use the Spot Healing Brush Tool: Enable 'Sample All Layers', click at the start of the line, hold Shift, and click at the end to remove the line.
For removing braces or small details, use the Brush Tool: Create a new layer, sample the tooth color (Alt/Option + click), and paint over the braces.
Adjust the brush hardness and opacity to blend the painted area smoothly with the surrounding area.
Repeat the painting process for each tooth or detail until the braces are removed.

subgoal: For objects with perspective, use the Vanishing Point filter to define the perspective and clone accordingly.
original_subgoals: Define the perspective using Vanishing Point:
Create a new layer for perspective removal.
Go to Filter > Vanishing Point.
Use the Create Plane tool (shortcut C) to mark the four corners of the area with perspective.
Adjust the points to align accurately with the perspective.
Clone in perspective:
Use the Clone tool within the Vanishing Point dialog to sample and paint, ensuring lines match the perspective.
Adjust Clone tool settings: set hardness to 0, and decide whether to use Healing based on the need for texture matching.
Paint in small sections to maintain control and smooth tones.

subgoal: Review the result and make final adjustments if necessary, ensuring the image looks seamless.
original_subgoals: Finish with final touch-ups:
Use the Polygonal Lasso tool to select any remaining areas needing correction.
Feather the selection slightly.
Use the Clone Stamp tool to sample and paint over the selected area.
Deselect with Ctrl (or Command) D.
Deselect the selection using Ctrl or Command + D.
Check the preview on the right to see how the fill looks.
Once satisfied with the preview, choose to output the result to a new layer.
Click 'OK' to apply the changes and remove the object from the image.
Review the variations provided and select the one that looks best.
To use the new Remove Tool, ensure you have the Photoshop Beta version installed.
Open the Creative Cloud application, go to the Beta Apps section, and install Photoshop Beta if not already installed.
Select the Remove Tool from the Healing group in the toolbar.
Paint over the object you want to remove and observe the result.
If needed, paint over any remaining imperfections to fix them.
Use the 'Sample All Layers' option for non-destructive editing by creating a new layer and enabling this option.
Use the 'Remove After Each Stroke' option to apply changes after each stroke or after multiple strokes as needed.
For complex areas, use selections to protect certain parts of the image while using the Remove Tool.
To touch up the removal, duplicate the layers (Ctrl + J) and merge them (Ctrl + E).
Use the Clone Stamp Tool with a low flow and opacity to blend the area, holding Alt to select a reference point and painting carefully to achieve a natural blend.
For smaller objects, use the Remove tool by creating a new layer and enabling 'Sample All Layers'.
Paint over the small objects you want to remove and press Enter to apply the changes.
To fix any issues with the generative fill, use the Object Selection tool to select the area you want to restore.
With the selection active, mask out the problem areas on the generative fill layer using a black brush.
Invert the selection to mask out additional problem areas if needed.
Use the Remove tool to touch up any remaining areas, ensuring 'Sample All Layers' is enabled.
For final touch-ups, use the Lasso tool to create a smaller selection and apply Generative Fill again.
Review the image to ensure all objects are removed and the perspective is consistent.
Compare results using the History panel to save different states and evaluate the effectiveness of each tool.
Review the image to ensure the object removal is seamless.
Review the final image to ensure all unwanted objects are removed and the image looks seamless.
